H0.text: The Moon to revolve once determines the length of one day on Earth.

H1.text: The length of one day on Earth is determined by how long it takes the Moon to rotate once.

H2.text: Earth to rotate once determines the length of one day on Earth.

H3.text: Earth to revolve once determines the length of one day on Earth.

A4.text: Over millions of years, Earth's rotation has been slowed significantly by tidal acceleration through gravitational interactions with the Moon.

A5.text: The true solar day tends to be longer near perihelion when the Sun apparently moves along the ecliptic through a greater angle than usual, taking about 10 seconds longer to do so.
